chapterTitle: Introduction to Valuation:The Time Value of Money

columns.text:
### Requirement 1 ###

We are asked what do future value of investment means.
Future value refers to how much money an investment could be worth after some period of time at a given interest rate.

### Requirement 2 ###

We are asked what do compound interest means and how does it differ from simple interest.

When an investment is compounded, it earns interest both on the original amount invested and the interest reinvested from a prior period. This is different from simple interest, in which the interest is only earned on the original principal investment.

### Requirement 3 ###

We are asked what is the future value of $1 invested at r per period for t periods.

The future value of $1 invested at r per period for t periods is:

$$
\begin{align*}
\text{Future Value} &= \$1 \times (1+ r)^t
\end{align*}
$$

wherein, 

$(1+ r)^t$ - is the future value factor of \$1 at $r$ percent for $t$ periods.
In this exercise, we must define the future value of an investment, analyze the given statement, and calculate the future value using the given information.

a) Even in monetary terms, the time has a monetary worth. An amount increases in value over time. The value of money obtained today differs from the value of money received one year later. For example, the current worth of $100 will not be the same after one year, five years, or ten years.  The value of the investment after one year is known as the **Future Value**. Therefore,  the future value of an investment is equal to the sum of the present value and the time value. The time value of a sum is determined by the interest rate at which it is compounded and the length of the periods involved.

b) Compounding interest refers to generating interest on interest, hence the resulting interest is known as compound interest. Compounding interest is computed not only on the original capital but also on the interest that has accrued over the course of many periods of time.  Compound interest varies from simple interest in that the interest is not reinvested, and so interest is earned on the original principal each month. Therefore, simple interest is only calculated on the principal amount. And this is the most significant distinction between these two concepts.

c) The present value of an asset is connected to its future value when the interest rate and time periods are considered. The following equation is a formula for calculating future value:

$$\text{FV} = \text{PV}( 1 + \text{r} )^{\text{t}}$$

Where:

FV = Future Value

PV = Present Value

r = Interest Rate

t = Number of Periods

According to the provided information, we can see that the present value (PV) is $1, so we will  substitute the given value into equation from step 4 as follows:

$$\text{FV} = \text{1}\cdot( 1 + \text{r} )^{\text{t}}$$
